title: What are a few recommended books on literature? - Quora

response.answer_text: For anyone interested, I compiled the responses to my previous question, "which book should you read at least once in your life?" into a list! I've chosen the ones that came up the most as well as the heavily upvoted responses and these were the 27 books I managed to come up with (in no particular order). Obviously there are so many more amazing books which aren't on here and equally deserve to be mentioned but if I were to list them all I'd be here a very long time. Hope there's some of you who might find his interesting and if you have any further books you might want to add or discuss then do comment!! The Brothers Karamazov - DostoevskyThe Phantom Toll Booth - Norton JusterThe Things They Carried - Tim O'BrienFlowers for Algernon - Daniel KeyesThe Yellow Wallpaper - Charlotte Perkins GilmanMeditations - Marcus AureliusBrave New World - Aldous HuxleySlaughterhouse Five - Kurt VonnegutThe Stand - Stephen KingOf Mice and Men - SteinbeckCatch 22 - Joseph HellerMaus - Art SpiegelmanThe Adventures of Huckleberry Finn - Mark TwainThe Stranger - Albert CamusThe Essential Calvin and Hobbes: a Calvin and Hobbes treasury - Bill WatersonReligious Texts (Bible, The Quran, Shruti and others)The Count of Monte Cristo - Alexandre DumasTo Kill a Mockingbird - Harper Lee1984 - George OrwellThe Lord of the Rings - J.R.R.TolkienHitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy - Douglas AdamsSiddhartha - Herman HesseNight - Elie WieselThe Last Question - Isaac AsimovOne Hundred Years of Solitude - Garcia MarquezEast of Eden - John SteinbeckAll Quiet on the Western Front - Erich Maria RemarqueThe Kite runner - Khaled hossieni

These are some of the books which are part of my book shelves. However, some of these are unread, so I'm looking forward to read them. 1. Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen 2. 1984 by George Orwell 3. The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald 4. Jane Eyre by Charlotte Brontë 5. Crime and Punishment by Fyodor Dostoyevsky 6. Lolita by Vladimir Nabokov 7. Wuthering Heights by Emily Brontë 8. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain 9. Of Mice and Men by John Steinbeck10. The Count of Monte Cristo by Alexandre Dumas 11. Brave New World by Aldous Huxley12. One Hundred Years of Solitude by Gabriel Garcí­a Márquez 13. Anna Karenina by Leo Tolstoy14. The Brothers Karamazov by Fyodor Dostoyevsky 15. Catch-22 by Joseph Heller16. The Grapes of Wrath by John Steinbeck 17. Slaughterhouse-Five by Kurt Vonnegut 18. A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens 19. War and Peace by Leo Tolstoy20. The Old Man and the Sea by Ernest Hemingway 21. Moby-Dick; or, the Whale by Herman Melville 22. Don Quixote by Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra 23. The Metamorphosis and Other Stories by Franz Kafka 24. East of Eden by John Steinbeck25. The Sound and the Fury by William Faulkner 26. All Quiet on the Western Front by Erich Maria Remarque 27. Ulysses by James Joyce28. The Scarlet Letter by Nathaniel Hawthorne 29. The Name of the Rose by Umberto Eco 30. The Master and Margarita by Mikhail Bulgakov 31. Candide by Voltaire32. David Copperfield by Charles Dickens 33. To the Lighthouse by Virginia Woolf 34. The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger35. For Whom the Bell Tolls by Ernest Hemingway 36. Invisible Man by Ralph Ellison37. Tess of the D’Urbervilles by Thomas Hardy 38. The Plague by Albert Camus39. The Heart is a Lonely Hunter by Carson McCullers 40. Things Fall Apart (The African Trilogy, #1) by Chinua Achebe 41. Their Eyes Were Watching God by Zora Neale Hurston 42. Brides head Revisited by Evelyn Waugh 43. A Confederacy of Dunces by John Kennedy Toole 44. Blindness (Blindness, #1) by José Saramago 45. The Awakening by Kate Chopin46. Blood Meridian, or the Evening Redness in the West by Cormac McCarthy 47. Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace 48. I, Claudius (Claudius, #1) by Robert Graves 49. Sons and Lovers by D.H. Lawrence50. In Search of Lost Time by Marcel Proust 51. Middlemarch/Silas Marner/Amos Barton by George Eliot 52. My Antonia by Willa Cather53. Light in August by William Faulkner 54. Vanity Fair by William Makepeace Thackeray 55. All the King's Men by Robert Penn Warren 56. The Tin Drum by Günter Grass57. Ficciones by Jorge Luis Borges 58. To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee59. Pale Fire by Vladimir Nabokov 60. The House of Mirth by Edith Wharton61. The Magic Mountain by Thomas Mann 62. Dead Souls by Nikolai Gogol 63. The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling by Henry Fielding 64. Tropic of Cancer by Henry Miller65. The Maltese Falcon, the Thin Man, Red Harvest by Dashiell Hammett 66. The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman by Laurence Sterne  Hope it helps. Thank you!
